content: Hey so we have our meeting today -- I'd be curious if as part of that meeting we could take a bit of stock of the things we've been working on and their status. I was talking a bit with @ag_dubs about the functioning of the group and how we might sharpen it and help us get overall traction, and it seemed like taking stock of where we're at would be a good first step. I at least feel a bit lost about it.
I'm sorry, I've had some unexpected interruptions today and will probably not be able to participate in the meeting

Hello everyone, It's time for the bi-weekly @WG-governance meeting! (React with :wave: to show attendance.) Today's agenda is as mentioned above by Niko, reviewing the current status of the Working Group.
I forget how we do it, is there a hackmd or something for taking notes?
We have an agenda hackmd. https://hackmd.io/ATj1rZJaRimaIfIWfAOYfQ
Definitely relatively limited attendance this week
So yeah I was thinking that I would kind of like to narrow back on what are the things we're actively working on
For example, we have a number of issues on the repository, and I remember us doing some work on some of those
And some of them are assigned :)
I think the most recent thing we've been working on has been the org taxonomy. https://hackmd.io/KHGL4YVPRU6QaEKoorBhrQ
Yeah, which doesn't exactly have an issue, unless it falls under "Domain working groups"
which is sort of does
Yeah, though probably would be good to have a new issue.
Can we say in a word what our "goal" is with that work?
A RFC(s)
I think it is something like "to settle on a limited set of concepts that cover the sorts of official groups within the Rust org and their responsibitilies"?
works for me
and probably the follow-up of "describing the existing teams etc in that structure"?
we could also say "to clarify" rather than "to settle", but I am good either way
maybe "to define" ?
I like "to define"
I'm typing in the agenda hackmd btw
OK, I think another effort has been the Github access policy
which in turn is connected to "codifying" groups into the team repository, so that we can use them as the basis for access rights etc, right?
that is true
yes indeed
that one has mainly been held up by questions of whether GitHub will add feature that make the RFC unnecessary
but it did help us codify groups into the team repository, as you said
I don't remember exactly what was in the RFC
but it seems unlikely it would become fully unnecessary
agreed
we definitely need the codification that is there
in particular I think the idea of trying to ensure that repositories belong to some group of folks
https://github.com/nellshamrell/rfcs/blob/add-github-access-policy-rfc/text/0000-github-access-policy.md

but parts of the RFC may be made unnecessary - anyway, it's out of the scope of this meeting - but I think that is something we should push through even if GitHub later adds features that make parts of it unnecessary
I'll talk with @Pietro Albini about it
PR Thread: https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2872
It looks like that RFC could be FCP'ed. Everyone seems to be in consensus.
I would be happy to land it as is
and revise if/when GitHub releases new features
ok - that is fine by me
so we should add a separate goal I think of "reflect group structure in the team repo"?
i.e., in terms of high-level bullets
I feel like @XAMPPRocky this is partly what the Rust By Example question stems from, right?
In particular I also feel like there was some big list of repositories
that we had to work our way through
Yeah, I would say the goal is something "having an accurate representation of the current membership in the Rust structure".
and I think we kind of stalled out on that
(that is maybe a separate goal though)
(I'd kinda wait to land that RFC)
@nikomatsakis That has been moving just very slowly. This most accurate list now is just the list on the nursery page. https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery
OK, I don't have a strong opinion. I'd be curious to hear more about just what might change (I think we discussed it once) but I appreciate you probably can't talk about it publicly
@XAMPPRocky so maybe a goal there was "deprecate rust-lang-nursery"
similarly I think we had a definite goal of "figure out what to do with the domain working groups"
that feels like part of "org taxonomy" but also kind of distinct?
I think domain working groups kinda got mixed with figuring out the org's structure.
I think it's distinct in there's an action item to close the existing applications for domain working group.
:angel: I know I was supposed to do that
had that on my to-do list for a minute
it seems distinct to me though in that
well it's basically just a really important sub-bullet somehow
maybe that's all :)
OK, are there other active goals...
I have a minor one, I'm not sure how much it's part of this group, but this group seems like a decent home for it :)
https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/issues/38
basically removing the idea of "pre-FCP"
I think this is essentially just waiting on a PR ;)
I'm fine with that
it fits into a kind of 'meta goal' of revisiting the RFC process and staged development
Would we consider project groups "in flight"?
(side note that I think there is clear evidence of confusion between the compiler-team and lang-team MCP procedures, and I'm interested in trying to "consolidate" them into one repository)

XAMPPRocky said:

Would we consider project groups "in flight"?

a good question, I think they're kind of bundled in with this idea of staged development, right?
but also kind of distinct I suppose
Yeah, and I would like to do a retro or two with some groups but I feel that's mostly landed to continue the metaphor.
I'm trying to decide here then
one separate thing I wouldn't mind listing is what we see as our accomplishments thus far :)
but anyway I think we can make a bullet for project-groups
I'm kind of seeing a skill-tree in the making here :)
you were asking @XAMPPRocky what we might do to improve the repository btw --
Heh - one accomplishment - my work with this team played a big part in getting me a job at Mozilla :)
I think it'd be great if these "active goals" were reflecte don our README.md, for example, or very easily found, with updates as to their status
maybe using a project board with one column per goal might work too
not sure that's quite the sort of accomplishment I had in mind ;)
I actually think we've done a lot of things, it's just nice to write them out
Sure I'm open to trying out a project board, that's pretty easy to maintain.
@XAMPPRocky I think btw we never quite finished the project group work
Ehm, I think there's a lot of little things.
in particular, I think that for it to be fully complete, I'd want to see the team repo updated so that I can write liaison = [...]
and webpage etc
I'll make an issue for those after this meeting :slight_smile:
I'm in support for getting rid of the prefcp
OK, it seems like we're approaching a complete list in the hackmd of ongoing activites etc?

I'm pondering what to do with the remaining time -- one thing I was thinking about was discussing a bit about how to push some of these items forward. I'm wondering in particular about interactions with teams.
looks like it
One other thing that I remember early on having in mind
and I'm not sure how mcuh we've done
we probably should have a policy of updating issues when they're discussed
is helping to codify policy where it was absent
I guess we have but mostly around org taxonomy etc
yeah
I'm thinking about how in the compiler team we're wrestling with things like the Tier RFC
also: one thing that we _were_ working on but kinda stopped was researching other governance structures to improve our own
we gotta trick @Josh Triplett into joining this group :)
I guess I feel a bit like I would like more support for things like "deciding what should be the policy to add a new tier"
or the policy to add a new compiler option to the compiler
like, I wrote that up
... but I'm not 100% sure of what's in there, and I would've loved to have somebody else helping to survey the people who might have an opinion and see it through ...
just thinking out loud :)
(that said, I think we also need to focus on one thing at a time, so i'm not trying to create new tasks)
@XAMPPRocky in terms of the "fit things into the team repository" work, I guess that "update to accomodate removal of docs team" is kind of a sub-bullet there, right?

(ps, side note, @Manish Goregaokar in the lang-team meeting about path to membership we discussed a lot your idea of facilitators; we never quite landed on the right way to incorporate that as an official concept, but I'm warming to it...)
@nikomatsakis I would maybe like to expand that to "create a process around creating and archiving teams", as I think it's all related.
expand what exactly?
one thing about creating teams that came to mind, related to the lang team membership process --
"update to accomodate removal of docs team"
and related to tiers, in a weird way --
ideally I think we wouldn't "create a team" as the first step, but reather, we'd more like "bless a team that already exists and is doing well"
in other words, thinking a bit about the terms we were using for path to membership, the idea was, can we open up all the activities a team member does, so that people can be doing them
and then we help guide people to doing them and, if it's going well, then we recognize that with membership

similarly, it seems like it'd be nice if we had a kind of set of 'things' a team should be doing, and we could kind of say "well, if there's a group of people pursuing this goal; having regular meetings; maintaining structure; etc"... anyway.
(that would be necessary, I imagine, but not sufficient)
Maybe creation was bad choice of words, but if I understand you correctly and reading the taxonomy doc a new top-level team would be made from a pre-existing productive sub-team?
it depends on which taxonomy doc we use
but basically I just mean that the question would be like:
actually I think this fits a bit better the notion of organizing by "activity"
i.e., maybe you say "I want us to be better about X", so I'll start by making a "notification group" for X
then from there maybe I run some weekly meetings and develop a skill tree and roadmap,
once I've done that and it's working ok, we say "ok, that's a project group" -- i.e., we recognize the structure that exists

then the group can start to make decisions internally (like the embedded group does) and so forth, and be doing that productively for a while, and it's like "ok, that's a team" -- maybe those decisions have to be ratified by a parent team in the beginning, but they're basically presented with "here is what we thought and why"
basically we have some set of things that distinguish each level from the next, and you can kind of build up those things, and then we recognize that they're built
but I do think we want a bit of a "is this a thing we even want to do" before you get started ;)
it's a bit tricky, it comes back to the question of "once we make a zulip stream, things look awfully official", perhaps...
anyway, I digress a bit

XAMPPRocky said:

"update to accomodate removal of docs team"

are you seeing this as its own bullet?
Hmm, I'm not sure to be honest.
I think it falls under "Reflect group structure in the team repository", but it just highlights that a big part of that work
Yeah I agree.
is figuring out what things out to be when they're kind of unclear
kind of like "remove rust-lang-nursery" or "apply an access policy"
speaking of which, well, I guess we're at the end of the meeting, but I'm happy to discuss the best way for us to move forward on unblocking that further
Oh I missed that it was an inncomplete sentence, but I agree with your point anyway. :slight_smile:
I can never tell how often to press Ctrl-Return
obviously I tend to favor "more rather than less" :)
Well what do people feel we should discuss at the next meeting before we close?
I'm pondering :)

I guess I think I'd be interested to continue our discussion of org taxonomy as a preliminary topic, subject to some possible revision. I might try to prepare before then a sketch of what an "activity-based taxonomy" might look like.
I think I would like to continue with the taxonomy work if there's nothing else pressing, it touches a lot of areas.

(that said, in the interim, I'm also interested in working to revise the repo to reflect and call out these priorities -- I also think this is a pretty big list, so it'd be nice if we could kind of have an issue for each one with assignee and sort of see that we're really making progess.)
Okay well , that concludes the meeting for today! Thank you everyone for attending, stay safe!
(but I think that should be done out of band.)
Yes, I was thinking about what about taking the time rewrite parts of the charter as while the high level goals might still be similar the content has meaningfully changed.
I'll at least start off by making the project board we discussed with all of the topics from hackmd today.
@nikomatsakis I would love to participate; the timing is kinda bad for me and it keeps conflicting with things, so I find myself not seeing the meetings until after they've happened.
@nikomatsakis good to hear! i'm happy to discuss it more if y'all want

nikomatsakis said:

(but I think that should be done out of band.)

Are there out-of-band tasks I can help with? The "C unwind" RFC seems like it's in a reasonably good place right now
